biocGO: describe relationship between Gene Ontology and Bioconductor

Vincent J. Carey

stvjc at channing.harvard.edu

Ludwig Geistlinger

ludwig_geistlinger at hms.harvard.edu

September 29, 2021

Source: vignettes/biocGO.Rmd
biocGO.Rmd

Introduction

Gene Ontology reaches into Bioconductor in many ways. This vignette sketches the key resources and connections.

GO.db

GO.db is an annotation package used through an R API defined in AnnotationDbi. The package is installable using BiocManager::install.

The basic R API

Here is how we can acquire some tags and the associated terms.

library(GO.db)
GO.db
## GODb object:
## | GOSOURCENAME: Gene Ontology
## | GOSOURCEURL: http://current.geneontology.org/ontology/go-basic.obo
## | GOSOURCEDATE: 2021-02-01
## | Db type: GODb
## | package: AnnotationDbi
## | DBSCHEMA: GO_DB
## | GOEGSOURCEDATE: 2021-Apr14
## | GOEGSOURCENAME: Entrez Gene
## | GOEGSOURCEURL: ftp://ftp.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene/DATA
## | DBSCHEMAVERSION: 2.1
## 
## Please see: help('select') for usage information
lk = keys(GO.db)[1:10]
lk
##  [1] "GO:0000001" "GO:0000002" "GO:0000003" "GO:0000006" "GO:0000007" "GO:0000009" "GO:0000010"
##  [8] "GO:0000011" "GO:0000012" "GO:0000014"
tt = AnnotationDbi::select(GO.db, keys=lk, columns="TERM")
## 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns
tt
##          GOID                                                     TERM
## 1  GO:0000001                                mitochondrion inheritance
## 2  GO:0000002                         mitochondrial genome maintenance
## 3  GO:0000003                                             reproduction
## 4  GO:0000006    high-affinity zinc transmembrane transporter activity
## 5  GO:0000007 low-affinity zinc ion transmembrane transporter activity
## 6  GO:0000009                   alpha-1,6-mannosyltransferase activity
## 7  GO:0000010                trans-hexaprenyltranstransferase activity
## 8  GO:0000011                                      vacuole inheritance
## 9  GO:0000012                               single strand break repair
## 10 GO:0000014       single-stranded DNA endodeoxyribonuclease activity

Relationships

ls("package:GO.db")
##  [1] "GO"            "GO_dbconn"     "GO_dbfile"     "GO_dbInfo"     "GO_dbschema"   "GO.db"        
##  [7] "GOBPANCESTOR"  "GOBPCHILDREN"  "GOBPOFFSPRING" "GOBPPARENTS"   "GOCCANCESTOR"  "GOCCCHILDREN" 
## [13] "GOCCOFFSPRING" "GOCCPARENTS"   "GOMAPCOUNTS"   "GOMFANCESTOR"  "GOMFCHILDREN"  "GOMFOFFSPRING"
## [19] "GOMFPARENTS"   "GOOBSOLETE"    "GOSYNONYM"     "GOTERM"

The GO{BP,MF,CC}* entities listed here are special R environments that can be queried.

get("GO:0000012", GOBPCHILDREN)
##            regulates negatively regulates positively regulates                  isa 
##         "GO:1903516"         "GO:1903517"         "GO:1903518"         "GO:1903823" 
##                  isa 
##         "GO:1990396"

The recorded relationships for BP terms are:

kk = keys(GO.db)
allc = mget(kk, GOBPCHILDREN, ifnotfound=NA)
table(unlist(sapply(allc, names)))
## 
##                  isa negatively regulates              part of positively regulates 
##                53015                 2768                 5191                 2756 
##            regulates 
##                 3216

For other subontologies:

allm = mget(kk, GOMFCHILDREN, ifnotfound=NA)
table(unlist(sapply(allm, names)))
## 
##     isa part of 
##   13631      11
allcc = mget(kk, GOCCCHILDREN, ifnotfound=NA)
table(unlist(sapply(allcc, names)))
## 
##     isa part of 
##    4863    1985

Dependent packages

Bioconductor software packages that use GO.db are:

reverse dependencies

OrgDb packages – mapping GO to genes via NCBI

org.Hs.eg.db is a package that uses NCBI mappings between human genes and GO terms to help annotate genes. Here, we use it to obtain all genes directly annotated to a GO term.

library(org.Hs.eg.db)
library(dplyr)
syms = AnnotationDbi::select(org.Hs.eg.db, keys=lk, keytype="GO", columns="SYMBOL")
## 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns
head(left_join(mutate(tt, GO=GOID), syms, by="GO"),15)
##          GOID                             TERM         GO EVIDENCE ONTOLOGY   SYMBOL
## 1  GO:0000001        mitochondrion inheritance GO:0000001     <NA>     <NA>     <NA>
## 2  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002      TAS       BP  SLC25A4
## 3  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002      IMP       BP     TYMP
## 4  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002      ISS       BP    MEF2A
## 5  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002      IMP       BP    MPV17
## 6  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002      IMP       BP     OPA1
## 7  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002      NAS       BP    LONP1
## 8  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002      IMP       BP     AKT3
## 9  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002      IDA       BP SLC25A36
## 10 GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002      IEA       BP     PIF1
## 11 GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002      IDA       BP SLC25A33
## 12 GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002      IMP       BP    MGME1
## 13 GO:0000003                     reproduction GO:0000003      IBA       BP    GNRH1
## 14 GO:0000003                     reproduction GO:0000003      IBA       BP    GNRH2
## 15 GO:0000003                     reproduction GO:0000003      IEP       BP   MMP23B

To obtain all genes annotated to a GO term OR TO ONE OF ITS CHILD NODES in the GO ontology:

syms.all = AnnotationDbi::select(org.Hs.eg.db, keys=lk, keytype="GOALL", columns="SYMBOL")
## 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns
head(left_join(mutate(tt, GOALL=GOID), syms.all, by="GOALL"),15)
##          GOID                             TERM      GOALL EVIDENCEALL ONTOLOGYALL   SYMBOL
## 1  GO:0000001        mitochondrion inheritance GO:0000001        <NA>        <NA>     <NA>
## 2  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         IMP          BP    PARP1
## 3  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         TAS          BP  SLC25A4
## 4  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         IDA          BP     DNA2
## 5  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         IMP          BP     TYMP
## 6  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         IBA          BP     LIG3
## 7  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         ISS          BP    MEF2A
## 8  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         IMP          BP    MPV17
## 9  GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         IMP          BP     OPA1
## 10 GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         IMP          BP    TOP3A
## 11 GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         IEA          BP     TP53
## 12 GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         NAS          BP    LONP1
## 13 GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         IMP          BP     AKT3
## 14 GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         IEA          BP PPARGC1A
## 15 GO:0000002 mitochondrial genome maintenance GO:0000002         IEA          BP    POLG2

Gene to GO mappings can be obtained in a similar fashion also for other model organisms:

OrgDb packages for model organisms

OrgDb annotation objects for non-model organisms can be obtained via AnnotationHub.

ah <- AnnotationHub::AnnotationHub()
## snapshotDate(): 2021-05-18
AnnotationHub::query(ah, "OrgDb")
## AnnotationHub with 1744 records
## # snapshotDate(): 2021-05-18
## # $dataprovider: ftp://ftp.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene/DATA/
## # $species: Escherichia coli, greater Indian_fruit_bat, Zythia rabiei, Zymoseptoria tritici_IPO3...
## # $rdataclass: OrgDb
## # additional mcols(): taxonomyid, genome, description, coordinate_1_based, maintainer,
## #   rdatadateadded, preparerclass, tags, rdatapath, sourceurl, sourcetype 
## # retrieve records with, e.g., 'object[["AH92572"]]' 
## 
##             title                                     
##   AH92572 | org.Ag.eg.db.sqlite                       
##   AH92573 | org.At.tair.db.sqlite                     
##   AH92574 | org.Bt.eg.db.sqlite                       
##   AH92575 | org.Cf.eg.db.sqlite                       
##   AH92576 | org.Gg.eg.db.sqlite                       
##   ...       ...                                       
##   AH95560 | org.Linderina_pennispora.eg.sqlite        
##   AH95561 | org.Daldinia_childiae.eg.sqlite           
##   AH95562 | org.Aspergillus_nidulans_FGSC_A4.eg.sqlite
##   AH95563 | org.Emericella_nidulans_FGSC_A4.eg.sqlite 
##   AH95564 | org.Talaromyces_atroroseus.eg.sqlite

biocView: GO used for 73 packages in Bioc 3.13

Bioconductor package contributors are required to provide tags for their packages derived from a vocabulary called biocViews. “GO” is a tag and 73 packages in Bioconductor 3.13 use it to describe their objective.

biocView GO

Filter the landing pages for Bioc 3.13 packages self-describing with the ‘GO’ tag here.

For Bioconductor 3.14 packages in development, see here.

GO enrichment analysis

A popular use case for GO annotations is GO enrichment analysis. A variety of methods are available in Bioconductor for that purpose, and can typically be divided into (i) methods that treat GO annotations as gene sets, and (ii) methods that account for the topology of the GO graph.

Methods that treat GO annotations as gene sets

Among the most used representatives of this class of methods are

  • limma::goana which performs classic over-representation analysis using a hypergeometric test as originally developed for the analysis of microarray data, and
  • GOSeq which conducts enrichment testing of GO terms while adjusting for gene length bias in RNA-seq data.

Methods that account for the topology of the GO graph

Among the most used representatives of this class of methods are

  • GOstats which performs a hypergeometric test that optionally conditions on the GO structure, and
  • topGO which implements different approaches (elim, weight, and parentchild) to reduce redundancy resulting from genes being annotated along the parent-child hierarchy.

Benchmarking of methods for GO enrichment analysis

The GSEABenchmarkeR package ships disease relevance scores for GO-BP and GO-MF terms. These relevance scores are aggregated per-gene disease relevance scores as obtained from the MalaCards database. This establishes some ground truth in a benchmarking setup, indicating which GO terms are considered relevant for a certain disease.

As an example, we inspect relevance scores of certain GO-BP terms for breast cancer:

data.dir <- system.file("extdata", package="GSEABenchmarkeR")
mala.gobp.file <- file.path(data.dir, "malacards", "GO_BP.rds")
mala.gobp <- readRDS(mala.gobp.file)
head(as.data.frame(mala.gobp$BRCA))
##                                                                    TITLE REL.SCORE MATCHED.GENES
## GO:0008284                     Positive Regulation of Cell Proliferation    166.10            78
## GO:0048010 Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor Receptor Signaling Pathway    135.71            56
## GO:0043066                      Negative Regulation of Apoptotic Process    123.02            67
## GO:0001934                Positive Regulation of Protein Phosphorylation    111.96            40
## GO:0007173            Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Signaling Pathway    111.09            52
## GO:0048015                       Phosphatidylinositol-mediated Signaling    110.84            37
##            TOTAL.GENES
## GO:0008284         491
## GO:0048010         281
## GO:0043066         530
## GO:0001934         151
## GO:0007173         323
## GO:0048015         121
